title: Belfagor
text:
Belfagor (premiere 26 April 1923) is an Italian-language <a href="opera">opera</a> by the composer <a href="Ottorino%20Respighi">Ottorino Respighi</a> to a <a href="libretto">libretto</a> by <a href="Claudio%20Guastalla">Claudio Guastalla</a> (1880–1948) based on the comedy "Belfagor" of <a href="Ercole%20Luigi%20Morselli">Ercole Luigi Morselli</a> (1882–1921), itself loosely based on the novella "<a href="Belfagor%20arcidiavolo">Belfagor arcidiavolo</a>" by <a href="Niccol%C3%B2%20Machiavelli">Niccolò Machiavelli</a>. It was premiered in 1923 at <a href="La%20Scala">La Scala</a> in Milan, under the baton of <a href="Antonio%20Guarnieri">Antonio Guarnieri</a>, since <a href="Arturo%20Toscanini">Toscanini</a> was unavailable. The cast featured Irish soprano <a href="Margaret%20Burke%20Sheridan">Margaret Burke Sheridan</a> as Candida, baritone <a href="Mariano%20Stabile">Mariano Stabile</a> as her lover Baldo, and tenor <a href="Francesco%20Merli">Francesco Merli</a> as the titular Belfagor, a "arcidiavolo" who tries to marry a human maiden while in disguise as a nobleman, using gifts of money to her father.
The première obtained a "full and warm" approval, with several curtain calls for the composer, but the opinion of the critics was divided, ranging from the enthusiasm of <a href="Filippo%20Tommaso%20Marinetti">Marinetti</a>, enchanted by the <a href="Futurism">futuristic</a> aspects of the opera, and of the music critic S. A. Lucani, to those who judged opera and libretto absolutely not enjoyable. wrote that this work looked like an attempt, not fully accomplished, to merge in a comic opera "the fabolous and the clownish, the miraculous and the sentimental" and that the comic expressivity was damaged by the absence of "assertiveness of the melodic plan and its capacity to develop rapidly".
Instrumentation.
"Belfagor" is scored for the following instruments:
<a href="piccolo">piccolo</a>, 2 <a href="Western%20concert%20flute">flutes</a>, 2 <a href="oboe">oboe</a>s, <a href="English%20horn">English horn</a>, <a href="E-flat%20clarinet">E-flat clarinet</a>, 2 <a href="clarinet">clarinet</a>s, 2 <a href="bassoon">bassoon</a>s, <a href="double%20bassoon">double bassoon</a>, 4 <a href="French%20horn">horns</a>, 3 <a href="trumpet">trumpet</a>s, 3 <a href="trombone">trombone</a>s, <a href="tuba">bass tuba</a>, <a href="timpani">timpani</a>, <a href="Triangle%20%28musical%20instrument%29">triangle</a>, <a href="Ratchet%20%28instrument%29">ratchet</a>, <a href="drum">drum</a>, <a href="bass%20drum">bass drum</a>, <a href="cymbal">cymbal</a>s, <a href="gong">tam-tam</a>, <a href="xylophone">xylophone</a>, <a href="handbell">handbell</a>s, <a href="bell">bell</a>s, <a href="celesta">celesta</a>, <a href="harp">harp</a>, <a href="String%20section">strings</a>.
Synopsis.
Prologue.
Belfagor appears in a small village. He explains to the apothecary Mirocleto, who has three daughters of marriageable age, to be on mission from the underworld. Belfagor has the task to discover if the marriage is truly a hell for the mankind, as many people arriving in the afterworld say. To accomplish his task Belfagor, who has a lot of money at his disposal, has to find a wife and spend ten years with her.
Act 1.
Belfagor turns up at Mirocleto's home, disguised as the handsome and immensely rich Ipsilonne. Fidelia and Maddalena are bewitched by Ipsilonne, but he chooses the third daughter, Candida, who instead shows disregard for him. Mirocleto and his wife, Olimpia, attracted by the money, consent to give Candida to Ipsilonne, but the girl is in despair, since she is in love with the sailor Baldo.
Act 2.
One month later, in a luxurious castle of Ipsilonne. Candida has been forced to marry Ipsilonne, but the marriage has not yet been consummated. Finally Candida, with the aid of Baldo, manages to flee, after making Ipsilonne believe that she would spend the night with him.
Epilogue.
Candida and Baldo find refuge thanks to the provost. Belfagor appears again in the village, this time disguised as a vagabond. Belfagor makes the doubt creep in Baldo, letting him believe that Candida lost her virginity with Ipsilonne, who this way achieved his aim of having fun with a young maiden before disappearing. Candida tries vainly to convince Baldo that the vagabond is a liar. Baldo gives in to her pleas only when Candida, in despair, asks the Madonna for a miracle, and the bells start playing by themselves.
